subject: Philosophy
title: The Sorites Paradox
description: A quick, practical guide to The Sorites Paradox.

hook.text: Remove one grain from a heap of sand. Still a heap. Keep removing. When exactly does it stop being a heap?

buildup.text: The sorites paradox shows that vague concepts â€” tall, rich, bald â€” have no precise boundary.

discovery.text: Each single grain removal seems harmless. But repeated enough, the heap vanishes. Where's the tipping point?

twist.text: There isn't one. Language is inherently vague. Precision is an ideal that many concepts can't achieve.

climax.text: This vagueness infects law, science, and daily life. When is someone legally 'competent'? Precisely how tall is 'tall'?

punchline.text: Not everything has a clear border. That's a feature, not a bug.

quiz.question: What does the sorites paradox reveal?
options: Many concepts are inherently vague with no precise boundaries
